subject: RE: [junit] How can I get Junit Test to run in parallel threads?
msgSnippet: On Thu, 2002-10-03 at 12:14, Michael Silverstein wrote: ... Dave: An excellent question indeed! I m not arguing your right to sell it.  I m just asking :-) The
messageBody:
On Thu, 2002-10-03 at 12:14, Michael Silverstein wrote:

Dave Astels wrote:
> Not to start a flame war... but why don't you follow Beck&Gamma's
> example and give it to the JUnit community as so many others have done
> with their extensions?

Dave:

An excellent question indeed!

I'm not arguing your right to sell it. I'm just asking :-)


The answer is that we are following the model that many companies such as
Sun (NetBeans->Forte), Red Hat, Suse etc. (Linux->branded Linux), Rational
(Eclipse->XDE), IBM (Eclipse->WSAD) pioneered, where they build commercial
tools that add to open source tools.

A little different though. Sun owns NetBeans (another example is
OpenOffice/StarOffice), IBM owns Eclipse. I bought one copy of RedHat
(5.2) but now that I have a high bandwith connection & CD burner I
download the ISO images. Rational is part of the Eclipse Consortium.

Don't forget that many commercial IDE vendors reship JUnit in an effort to
add value to their own products.

Yes. This, i think, would be a better comparison.

Likewise, there are people who earn their
living writing books and consulting around open source tools,

Like my upcoming JUnit oriented book :-)

or use open
source tools in one way or another to promote their own ventures. For
example, "The Coad Letter: Test-driven Development Edition, issue 102:
JUnit" written by yourself asks that the reader "consider Saorsa's intensive
5-day, Hands-on TDD course taught by Dave Astels." I assume you are not
giving this course away for free.

You assume correctly. That's also a different situation, though. But I
do see your point. If I could afford to give the course for free, I
would, but I can't so I won't.

In the case of Enhanced JUnit, it is a little strange because we are
actually grafting some functionality that already exists in an enterprise
testing tool (Test Mentor) onto JUnit. There is actually more code (and
functionality) in the add-on than JUnit.

Then it's more than an extension... more like the previous examples.. a
product based on an opensource project. Another example is ArgoUML &
Posidon


I hope this helps, Mike

I doesn't hurt :-)

Dave

________________________________________________________________________
Dave Astels
Coauthor of "A Practical Guide to XP"
Editor of the Test-Driven Development Edition of The Coad Letter
CEO & Master Software Craftsman

An Agile Software Studio
